projects.title: First Year of Bay Area Bike Sharing Service
projects.description:
I analyzed the open dataset of the Bay Area Bike Sharing Service's usage and weather data for the first year of its operation. This analysis was done two times using only RStudio and only Python with analytics packages.

The dataset contained departure and arrival stations and times for individual trips, location and names of stations, and weather data for the whole year. Based on this data, my aim was to uncover patterns of usage by time, location and weather conditions.

The project involved extensive data preparation and usage of Google's elevation API.
 
My analysis uncovered
- Clusters of stations and most frequent itineraries
- Spatiotemporal usage patterns
- Different user types and usage types
- 'Ideal' weather conditions, and change in usage based on weather

Findings could be used to fine-tune maintenance operations of the system, better targeting promotion, planning extensions, and a possible introduction of different passes based on usage types.

contributors.headline: Freelance Cloud Data Engineer & DataOps Consultant

projects.title: Mapping MEPs for Effective Lobbying
projects.description:
Using a web crawler, we created a dataset of Members of European Parliament (MEPs) containing their nationality, party affiliations, and membership to parliamentary committees. Using this dataset, we created a network of MEPs, based on joint membership in committees. Software used were Python, Excel and Gephi.

We were interested in increasing the efficiency of political lobbying, by identifying MEPs with the most influence on the legislative process. Our analysis uncovered the surprising insight that the most influential representatives are not the ones with highest political status, but the ones with memberships to some particular committees.

The findings could be used by advocacy organizations to more efficiently forward their agenda in the legislative process.

projects.title: San Fransisco Crime Patterns
projects.description:
The project for the above class consisted of two assignments:
1) Cluster detection and classification
2) Association rule mining

I analyzed the open dataset of crime records in San Fransisco using KNIME for the analysis and RStudio for data preparation.

Although the dataset wasn't large and full-featured, I have managed to uncover some potentially useful insights and patterns of crime in San Fransisco:
- when and where some crimes are most often committed
- which crimes go together
- some specific areas with particular crime patterns

In a non-academic setting, findings could have been used to better prepare police officers what to expect on a particular shift based on time and district of service.

projects.title: Y-GEN Kilátó Akadémia
projects.description:
Kilátó Akadémia was a three day summer camp for our youth organization with workshops on citizen engagement in local issues, panel discussions on select topics in politics and policy, and a lot of teambuilding and group fun.

I was one of two head organizers in charge of the preparation and on-site management of the event.

- Selected location
- Contacted and asked speakers to participate
- Managed all cash-flows
- Set up schedule
- Promoted event
- Coordinated with local partners for catering and accommodation
- Smoothly managed unforeseen changes and obstacles during the event

profile_positions.description:
Tech stack:
Python | SQL |  Postgres | Airflow |  Docker | Kubernetes | Linux | AWS

Alongside my data team lead role, I also fulfilled the data engineer role in the company:

- Built and managed a data warehouse: organization, permissions, performance tuning. (Postgres on Amazon RDS)

- Deployed automatic statistical data quality checks as a part of ETL using the great_expectaions python library via Apache Airflow
